learningObjectives: Recognize and identify cognitive biases (Anchoring, Confirmation, Framing) in a complex clinical case.
Develop a differential diagnosis for dyspnea in a patient with multiple comorbidities.
Understand the importance of medication reconciliation and its impact on diagnosis.
Evaluate the impact of systems-based errors (e.g., delayed test results) on patient outcomes.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for the past 2 months.
initialPresentation.historyOfPresentIllness: The patient is an elderly Spanish-speaking woman whose son provides the history. Her shortness of breath has gradually increased over 2 months and is worse with exertion. She has also had decreased oral intake and weight loss over the past few weeks. She denies chest pain, fevers, or chills. A 3-day course of azithromycin from her PCP 3 weeks ago provided no improvement.

informationBlocks.content: The patient speaks only Spanish and her son is the historian. Most of her medical records are from another health system.
Past Medical History includes: Morbid obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and rheumatoid arthritis.
Current medications are thought to be lisinopril, atenolol, glipizide, and metformin. The son is unsure about other medications, including those for rheumatoid arthritis.
The patient's son has noticed decreased oral intake and weight loss over the past few weeks.
Temperature is 99.9°F (37.7°C), heart rate 105, blood pressure 140/70, respiratory rate 24, oxygen saturation 89% on room air.
Pulmonary examination demonstrates crackles in all lung fields. [cite: 32]
Heart sounds are normal and there is no lower-extremity edema. [cite: 32]
Pro-brain-type natriuretic peptide (pro-BNP) level is greater than the upper limit of normal.
White blood cell count is elevated at 13.0 x 10^9/L.
The preliminary impression from the resident radiologist for the chest radiograph is 'consistent with pulmonary vascular congestion.'
The final attending radiologist's interpretation notes 'ill-defined, scattered, faint opacities,' suggesting a possible interstitial pattern.
Medication lists from previous hospitalizations arrive, revealing the patient has been receiving infliximab for her rheumatoid arthritis for the past 3-4 months.
An echocardiogram shows a normal ejection fraction with no evidence of elevated filling pressures.
Computed tomography of the chest reveals a reticular pattern with innumerable, tiny, 1- to 2-mm pulmonary nodules.

anchoring.anchorDescription: The initial, incorrect diagnosis of 'heart failure exacerbation' is anchored by the preliminary chest x-ray read suggesting pulmonary vascular congestion.
anchoring.contradictoryDescription: The normal echocardiogram result directly contradicts the diagnosis of severe heart failure, yet the team may fail to adjust their thinking.
